item.title: TGS 2025 concludes with 263,101 visitors; TGS 2026 set for September 17 to 21
item.content:encoded:
2026 to mark the first five-day event in show history.

Tokyo Game Show 2025, which ran from September 25 to 28 at Makuhari Messe in Chiba, Japan, concluded on Sunday with a total of 263,101 visitors over the four-day period, the Computer Entertainment Supplier’s Association announced.

Additionally, it was announced that Tokyo Game Show 2026 will run from September 17 to 21, 2026, marking the first-five day event in the show’s history. It will once again be held at Makuhari Messe in Chiba.

Here are the statistics from this year’s show compared against 2024 and 2023:

202520242023
Business Day 1September 25September 26September 21
52,352 people42,031 people33,706 people
Business Day 2September 26September 27September 22
54,779 people45,149 people36,109 people
General Public Day 1September 27September 28September 23
77,415 people97,786 people96,033 people
General Public Day 2September 28Setember 29September 24
78,555 people89,773 people77,390 people
Total263,101 people274,739 people243,238 people

Here is a the 2025 show summary from the Computer Entertainment Supplier’s Association:

With the theme “Unlimited, Neverending Playground,” Tokyo Game Show 2025 welcomed 1,136 exhibitors from 47 countries and regions, surpassing last year’s record. At Makuhari Messe, a wide range of new titles were unveiled across platforms from home consoles and smart devices to PC and virtual reality.

In addition, the exhibition showcased a diverse array of related products, services, solutions, and merchandise, reflecting the expanding scope of the gaming industry.

On the event stage, Tokyo Game Show presented a variety of programs, including the Keynote Speech, the Japan Game Awards 2025 Future Division ceremony, and a special lecture series in collaboration with the Agency for Cultural Affairs and the Japan Arts Council titled Top Game Creators Academy. These sessions offered valuable insights for young talent aspiring to enter the game industry.

Business negotiations were also highly active, with the Tokyo Game Show Business Matching System recording 3,591 appointments. Online, 21 official programs were streamed via Tokyo Game Show’s official accounts on YouTube, X, and Twitch, as well as on platforms such as Niconico.

For overseas audiences, Tokyo Game Show partnered with DouYu and bilibili in China, and with IGN in North America and Europe, to deliver content worldwide.



https://www.gematsu.com/2025/09/tgs-2025-concludes-with-263101-visitors-tgs-2026-set-for-september-17-to-21

item.title: The Relic: First Guardian launches in early 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

Dark fantasy action RPG gets a release window.

The Relic: First Guardian, a dark fantasy action RPG with Soulslike elements, will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam in early 2026, publisher Perp Games and Korean developer Project Cloud Games announced.

Here is an overview of the game, via Perp Games:

Inspired by Korean Folktales and Legends

Experience unique, blended gameplay, storytelling, and combat in this eight-minute slice of what’s soon to come. A rich tapestry of ancient tales is yearning to be unearthed where every story is woven into the fabric in the continent of Arsiltus—even amid combat. This is the unique experience awaiting in The Relic: First Guardian.

Bosses are Brutals

Featuring 70 formidable “Brutals,” each with a personal tale of sorrow, overcoming these massive bosses will require mastering the diverse combat system. Use a combination of unique weapons, magic, and skills tailored to your playstyle, all while crucially managing your stamina where every defense and dodge counts. Defeating each Brutal means The Last Guardian will inherit their tragic story, along with powerful special items and upgrades essential for progression.

Progression is Environmental

Exploring vast environments will lead you towards fragments that unlock more skills, armor, and weapons. Leave no stone unturned, no corner unexplored, and no dungeon uncompleted.

Watch a new trailer below. View a new set of screenshots at the gallery.

Release Window Gameplay Trailer

Extended Release Window Gameplay Trailer

Screenshots

  • ❮
  • ❯


https://www.gematsu.com/2025/09/the-relic-first-guardian-launches-in-early-2026

item.title: This Week’s Japanese Game Releases: Ghost of Yotei, Digimon Story: Time Stranger, Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles, more
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS4
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Switch 2
  • Xbox One
  • Xbox Series

Super Mario Galaxy + Super Mario Galaxy 2, UNYIELDER, etc.

Ghost of Yotei for PlayStation 5, Digimon Story: Time Stranger for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC, and Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, PlayStation 4, Switch, and PC are the highlights of this week’s Japanese video game releases.

Also due out this week is Super Mario Galaxy + Super Mario Galaxy 2 for Switch, UNYIELDER for PC, and the Early Access version of Genokids for PC.

Get the full list of this week’s Japanese game releases below. It should be noted that Gematsu will receive a small percentage of money from purchases made through Play-Asia links. You can also save five percent with our multi-use “GEMATSU2025” coupon code.

Physical and Digital

  • The Ancient Magus’ Bride: Midsummer Pilgrimage (Switch) – Launching digitally worldwide.
    • Special Edition (Switch)
  • Digimon Story: Time Stranger (PS5) – Launching worldwide.
      • Limited Edition (PS5)
      • Collector’s Edition (PS5)
    • North American Version
      • Standard Edition (PS5, Xbox Series)
      • Limited Edition (PS5, Xbox Series)
    • European Version (PS5, Xbox Series)
    • Asian Version
      • Standard Edition (PS5)
      • Collector’s Edition (PS5)
  • Ending the Happy Route (PS5)
  • Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles (PS5, Switch 2, PS4, Switch) – Switch 2 version is a code-in-a-box. Launching worldwide.
    • North American Version (PS5, Switch)
    • European Version (PS5, Switch)
    • Asian Version (PS5, Switch)
  • Ghost of Yotei (PS5) – Launching worldwide.
    • Collector’s Edition (PS5)
    • North American Version
      • Standard Edition (PS5)
    • European Version
      • Standard Edition (PS5)
      • Collector’s Edition (PS5)
    • Asian Version
      • Standard Edition (PS5)
      • Collector’s Edition (PS5)
  • Super Mario Galaxy + Super Mario Galaxy 2 (Switch)
    • North American Version (Switch)
    • European Version (Switch)

Digital

  • Alien: Rogue Incursion Evolved Edition (PS5, Xbox Series, PC [Steam, Epic Games Store]) – Launching worldwide.
  • The Ancient Magus’ Bride: Midsummer Pilgrimage (PS5, PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Buildest (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, Switch) – Launching worldwide.
  • Candy Rangers (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Castle of Heart: Retold (PS5, Xbox Series, Switch, PC [Steam, GOG]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Digimon Story: Time Stranger (Xbox Series, PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Echoes of the Plum Grove (Xbox Series, Xbox One, PC [Microsoft Store]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Ending the Happy Route (PS4, Switch, PC [Steam])
  • Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles (Xbox Series, PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Garten of Banban VIII: Anti Devil (PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Genokids Early Access (PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Go Fight Fantastic! (Xbox Series, Xbox One) – Launching worldwide.
  • LEGO Party! (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
    • North American Version (PS5, Xbox Series / Xbox One, Switch)
    • European Version (PS5, Xbox Series / Xbox One, Switch)
  • Magical Delicacy (PS5, PS4) – Launching worldwide.
  • MOUTHOLE (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, Switch) – Launching worldwide.
  • Mind Diver (PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.
  • Train Sim World 6 (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, PC [Steam, Epic Games Store]) – Launching worldwide.
  • UNYIELDER (PC [Steam]) – Launching worldwide.

The PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, and Switch titles listed above can be purchased through Japanese PlayStation Network and Nintendo accounts using prepaid cards:

  • PlayStation Store cards (yen): 1,100 / 3,000 / 5,000 / 10,000
  • Nintendo eShop cards (yen): 1,000 / 1,500 / 3,000 / 5,000 / 9,000

Demos, Betas, Updates, etc.

  • FBC: Firebreak “Breakpoint” Update (PS5, Xbox Series, PC)
  • KILLER INN Second Closed Beta Test Set (PC)
  • Monster Hunter Wilds “Title Update 3” (PS5, Xbox Series, PC)
  • Pokemon Trading Card Game Pocket “Deluxe Pack ex” Expansion (iOS, Android)
